statement:
The *double angle identities* are

$$\begin{aligned}
 \sin(2x) & = & 2\sin{x}\cos{x} \\
 \cos(2x) & = & \cos^2{x}-\sin^2{x} = 2\cos^2{x}-1 = 1-2\sin^2{x} \\
 \tan(2x) & = & \frac{2\tan{x}}{1-\tan^2{x}}\end{aligned}$$

These are all derived from their respective trigonometric addition
formulas. For example,

$$\begin{aligned}
 \sin(2x) & = & \sin(x+x) \\
          & = & \sin{x}\cos{x}+\cos{x}\sin{x} \\
          & = & 2\sin{x}\cos{x} \end{aligned}$$

The formula for cosine follows similarly, and the formula tangent is
derived by taking the ratio of sine to cosine, as always.

The double angle identities can also be derived from the de Moivre
identity.
